questions.answer: E. Corrupted LSAs exchanges between the R1 and R2.

choices.B: The R2 router has not received the OSPF hello packets from the R1 router.
choices.D: Mismatched OSPF hello interval configuration between the R1 and R2.
choices.A: DR and BDR election errors between R1 and R2.
choices.C: Mismatched interface maximum transmission unit (MTU) configuration between the R1 and R2.

questions.answer_description:
Explanation -
When a router receives an OSPF Hello from a neighbor, it sends the Hello packet by including that neighbor`s router ID in the Hello packet. If the neighbor does not receive this packet (means that it doesn`t see itself in this packet), it will be stuck in INIT state. INIT state can be understood as a one-way Hello. An example of a router stuck in INIT state is shown below:

discussion.content: B. The R2 router has not received the OSPF hello packets from the R1 router.

questions.question_text:
You have just completed an OSPF implementation. While executing your verification plan, you determine that R1 is not able to establish full OSPF adjacency with
R2. The show ip ospf neighbor command output on R1 shows that R2 is stuck in the INIT state.
What could be the cause of this problem?
questions.answer_ET: E. Corrupted LSAs exchanges between the R1 and R2.

discussion.content: E. The OSPF priority is set to 0 on both routers; therefore neither can become the DR.

questions.answer_description:
Explanation -
When OSPF adjacency is formed, a router goes through several state changes before it becomes fully adjacent with its neighbor. The states are Down, Attempt,
Init, 2-Way, Exstart, Exchange, Loading, and Full.
An OSPF neighbor reaches the 2-way state when bidirectional communication is established (each router has seen the other`s hello packet). This is the beginning of an OSPF adjacency. On broadcast media and non-broadcast multiaccess networks, the DR and BDR are elected in this state. But the priority on both routers are 0 so no DR and BDR are elected -> These routers stay in the 2-way state.
(Reference and a good resource of OSPF Neighbor states:
http://www.cisco.com/en/US/tech/tk365/technologies_tech_note09186a0080093f0e.shtml)

choices.B: You are attempting to run in the broadcast mode over an NBMA interface.
choices.D: Someone has changed the OSPF router ID; therefore you must clear the OSPF process.
choices.A: All OSPF implementations must have at least one interface in area 0.
choices.C: Both routers are configured to function as a BDR; therefore, there is no DR router.

questions.answer_ET: E. The OSPF priority is set to 0 on both routers; therefore neither can become the DR.
questions.answer: E. The OSPF priority is set to 0 on both routers; therefore neither can become the DR.
questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. You have completed an OSPF implementation, and you are verifying OSPF operation. You notice that router A and router B are stuck in the two-way state. From the show ip ospf interface command output, what is the cause of this issue?
//IMG//

discussion.content: B. The route will transition to the active state

choices.B: The route will transition to the active state
choices.A: EIGRP will find the interface with the lowest MAC address
choices.C: The route will transition to the passive state

questions.answer_description: When a route (current successor) goes down, the router first checks its topology table for a feasible successor but it cant find one. So it goes active on the that route to find a new successor by sending queries out to its neighbors requesting a path to the lost route.
questions.answer_ET: D. EIGRP will automatically use the route with the lowest feasible distance(FD)
questions.answer: D. EIGRP will automatically use the route with the lowest feasible distance(FD)
questions.question_text: After DUAL calculations, a router has identified a successor route, but no routes have qualified as a feasible successor. In the event that the current successor goes down, what process will EIGRP use in the selection of a new successor?

questions.answer_ET: D. EIGRP supports five generic packet types, including Hello, Update, Query, Reply, and ACK packets.
questions.question_text: Which three statements about the EIGRP routing protocol are true? (Choose three)

choices.A: EIGRP sends periodic hello packets to the multicast IP address 224.0.0.10.
choices.C: EIGRP will form a neighbor relationship with another peer even when their K values are mismatched.
choices.B: EIGRP will not form a neighbor relationship with another peer when their AS number and K values, either or both are mismatched.

questions.answer: D. EIGRP supports five generic packet types, including Hello, Update, Query, Reply, and ACK packets.

questions.answer_description: Metrics must be set manually via configuration when redistributing into RIP and EIGRP, whereas OSPF uses a default value of 20.
questions.question_text: Which two routing protocols require a metric to be configured when redistributing routes from other protocols? (Choose two.)
